title: UrbanetGh calls for establishment of seed centres
text:
16 July 2015 23:00 CET UrbanetGh calls for establishment of seed centres By GNA 
Tamale, July 16, GNA - Mr Zakaria Abdul-Rashid, Executive Director of UrbanetGh, a non-governmental organization, has called for a policy to encourage the establishment of seeds or input centres in the districts to make them accessible to farmers. 
He said farmers, mostly located in the rural areas, were aware of improved seeds and were ready to adopt them, but the non-availability of seed centres in the districts made it difficult for them to adopt the improved technologies. 
He said this was affecting agricultural productivity, and called for the establishment of seed centres in the districts, to enable farmers to adopt the improved technologies. 
Mr Abdul-Rashid made the call when he presented a summary of outcomes of district level policy discussions on soybean at a Northern Regional Policy Conference, organized by UrbanetGh in collaboration with United States Agency for International Development - Agricultural Policy Support Programme (USAID - APSP) in Tamale on Wednesday. 
The conference, which brought together a broad range of stakeholders in the soybean value chain, from about eight districts, for soybean production in the region including Tamale Metropolis, Savelugu/Nanton Municipality, Kumbungu, Sagnarigu, Karaga and Gusheigu, deliberated on critical policy issues relating to soybean production as a cash crop and a food and nutrition crop in the region. 
It was a follow-up to a series of activities, including the training of farmers on Agriculture Policies, such as the Food and Agriculture Sector Development Policy (FASDEP II), and Medium Term Agricultural Sector Improvement Programme (METASIP), and series of district level policy dialogue sessions held in the eight beneficiary districts. 
Mr Abdul-Rashid also called for a policy to create marketing opportunities for soybean farmers, by encouraging large-scale buyers of soybean, to go to the rural areas to buy soybeans to ensure ready demands for the produce. 
He also expressed the need for the Ministry of Food and Agriculture to support and build capacity of farmer-based organizations, to enable them to participate in policy discussions. 
Mr William Boakye-Acheampong, Northern Regional Director of the Department of Agriculture, advised farmers to undertake intensive agriculture by cultivating few acres, which would ensure proper management for better yields. 
Mr Boakye-Acheampong disclosed that government had come out with a number of policies, including FASDEP II, aimed at ensuring food security, and called for support from all and sundry, to ensure the success of the policies. 
Mr Festus Kwadzokpo, Capacity Building Specialist at the USAID - APSP, said the USAID - APSP's aim was to create the enabling environment for private sector investment in the agricultural sector, whilst supporting both government and the private sector to come out with policies to develop the agricultural sector.
